title: rbperf: A sampling profiler and tracer for Ruby which runs in BPF
description:
rbperf is a Ruby profiler I‚Äôve been working on that aims to incur low overhead, can be run against processes without having to modify or restart them and produces on-CPU profiles rather than accounting for ‚Äúwall‚Äù time.

It also has some basic tracing functionality that I am planning to extend. One of the features I want to add before the end of the year is allocation tracing. It can now trace system calls, so we can see exactly which Ruby code called a particular system call!

The BPF stack walker is written in C and compiled to BPF bytecode using clang, and the userspace bits are written in Rust, which has been a pleasure to use so far and I believe it‚Äôs a good fit for this project. It‚Äôs been my first ‚Äúreal‚Äù project in this language which has been a great learning experience.

I‚Äôm planning to write some posts on how rbperf works, why it‚Äôs been designed this way, and the many learnings along the way thus far :)

Would love to hear any feedback or ideas. I am still quite new to Rust, and I am sure that things can be improved a lot! Thanks!!
description_plain:
`rbperf` is a Ruby profiler I've been working on that aims to incur low overhead, can be run against processes without having to modify or restart them and produces on-CPU profiles rather than accounting for "wall" time.

It also has some basic tracing functionality that I am planning to extend. One of the features I want to add before the end of the year is allocation tracing. It can now trace system calls, so we can see exactly which Ruby code called a particular system call!

The BPF stack walker is written in C and compiled to BPF bytecode using clang, and the userspace bits are written in Rust, which has been a pleasure to use so far and I believe it's a good fit for this project. It's been my first "real" project in this language which has been a great learning experience.

I'm planning to write some posts on how `rbperf` works, why it's been designed this way, and the many learnings along the way thus far :)

Would love to hear any feedback or ideas. I am still quite new to Rust, and I am sure that things can be improved a lot! Thanks!!
